description: This course deals with methods of teaching mathematics. Materials are examined for their use in diagnosis, remediation and enrichment. ED 441J concentrates on the content and methodology of mathematics for secondary students. 3 semester hours

name: Mthds Math,MIDD
description: This course deals with methods of teaching mathematics. Materials are examined for their use in diagnosis, remediation and enrichment. ED 441M concentrates on the appropriate practices for middle school, grades 4-8, with an emphasis upon interdisciplinary connections. 3 semester hours

name: M/M Teaching Social Studies Elementary
description: This course assists students in developing competencies in unit planning, instructional strategies, and the utilization of diverse materials and technology for teaching the social studies. Students design courses of study that integrate state and national standards; contemporary thinking about the teaching of social studies is stressed. ED 442C concentrates on the activities, planning, and materials for social studies in elementary classrooms. 2 semester hours

name: M/M Teaching Social Studies Secondary
description: This course assists students in developing competencies in unit planning, instructional strategies, and the utilization of diverse materials and technology for teaching the social studies. Students design courses of study that integrate state and national standards; contemporary thinking about the teaching of social studies is stressed. ED 442J concentrates upon appropriate content, planning, and practices for 7-12 classrooms. 3 semester hours

name: M/M Teaching Social Studies Middle
description: This course assists students in developing competencies in unit planning, instructional strategies, and the utilization of diverse materials and technology for teaching the social studies. Students design courses of study that integrate state and national standards; contemporary thinking about the teaching of social studies is stressed. ED 442M concentrates on the content, practices, and planning appropriate for the middle level, grades 4-8. Interdisciplinary possibilities are examined. 3 semester hours

name: M/M Tchg Tchg Science,Elem
description: This course introduces teaching approaches, instructional materials, and contemporary thinking about science education. ED 443 C concentrates upon the practices and materials of effective science for elementary level. ED 443 C ? 2 semester hours

name: Mthds & Materials Science, Sec
description: This course introduces teaching approaches, instructional materials, and contemporary thinking about science education. ED 443J concentrates upon the appropriate content and practices for the secondary science curriculum. 3 semester hours

name: Methods and Materials in Teaching Scienc
description: This course introduces teaching approaches, instructional materials, and contemporary thinking about science education. ED 443 M concentrates upon the appropriate content and practices for the middle grades, 4-8. Interdisciplinary possibilities are examined. 3 semester hours

name: M/M Teach Business,Sec
description: This course focuses on various purposes of the business curriculum in a school setting. It examines the range of teaching strategies and materials for classroom practices. 3 semester hours

name: M/M Tchg for Lang
description: This course familiarizes the student with the major purposes of the study of foreign language in the schools. It introduces the strategies and classroom activities for effective teaching. It examines appropriate materials for teaching foreign languages. 3 semester hours

name: Tchg Engl As Second Lang
description: This course explores the language needs of children who are learning English as a second language. It reviews and explains effective methods and strategies for teaching such students. The most appropriate materials are identified and utilized. 3 semester hours

name: Field Experience
description: This course is a structured observation in a public school. The goals of the course are to facilitate the students? awareness of self, of school pupils, and of prospective teachers. Course can serve as an elective for other majors. The number of credits taken should be determined with the student?s advisor. Required prior to student teaching. 1 to 6 semester hours

name: Rsrch/Report Writing
description: This is an introduction to the research process, to the understanding of published research, and to the application of research findings to education. The course prepares the student to write formal papers and research reports. 3 semester hours

name: Differentiated Instruction:blgd Stud Div
description: This course focuses on pedagogy based on the philosophy that each student is a unique learner and that instruction should be provided that meets the needs of diverse students. Methods for addressing the needs of students? diverse strengths, background, experiences, gender, linguistic, and learning styles will be presented. It is recommended that the course will be taken after completion of EDU 564: Education of Students with Exceptionalities. 3 semester hours

name: Comp/Intl Educ
description: This is a comparative study of educational policies and practices in selected countries throughout the world. Global problems like peace, social and economic justice, and environmental quality are examined with a view to promoting global awareness in American education. 3 semester hours

name: Intercultural Relations
description: This course presents an overview of theories about educational, social and cultural problems of minority culture students, about teacher perceptions and expectations, about parental involvement. The course also critically analyzes policies and practices of multicultural and bilingual education. The thrust of the course is to develop appropriate and non-biased methods of teaching all children. 3 semester hours

name: Psyc Found Educ
description: This is concerned with the work of educators in general and teachers in particular. Topics include student characteristics (personality, growth, and development, adjustment, etc.) motivation, learning, measurement and evaluation, objectives, and teaching methods. 3 semester hours

name: Statuatory Requirements
description: This course addresses the topic required for Connecticut licensure in teaching, including topics in health and intergroup relations. 1 semester hour

name: Fund of Neuroscience for Educators
description: This course will provide participants the foundations for understanding the cognitive and neurological sciences associated with the processes of learning.  Participants will learn about the brain processes of storing and retrieving information, and will examine how current neuroscience research intersects with effective teaching and learning across content areas.  Topics of study will include the brain's memory systems, the impact of emotions of learning, the processes involved in higher order thinking and learning, and issues related to mental development.

name: Internship
description: In the first semester interns will work under supervision in a learning environment, providing a variety of paraprofessional services to the schools.

name: Adaptations: From Print to Film
description: This course will examine the source texts and film adaptations of literary works drawn from a variety of print genres, including short stories, fairy tales, novels, nonfiction journalism, and Shakespearean plays.  Each textual source and film is paired with another to provide illuminating case studies of both close and loose adaptations that compare and contrast on a larger scale.

name: Children's Literature
description: This surveys books and periodicals emphasizing criteria for selection and evaluation, procedures for establishing a program of literature in the schools, and opportunities to explore the interpretation of literature in the classroom through drama, story telling, book reporting, and choral speaking. Education 536C is focused on children?s literature. 2 semester hours

name: Adolescent Lit,sec
description: This surveys books and periodicals emphasizing criteria for selection and evaluation, procedures for establishing a program of literature in the schools, and opportunities to explore the interpretation of literature in the classroom through drama, story telling, book reporting, and choral speaking. Education 536J concentrates on adolescent literature. 3 semester hours

name: Adolescent Literature, Middle School
description: This surveys books and periodicals emphasizing criteria for selection and evaluation, procedures for establishing a program of literature in the schools, and opportunities to explore the interpretation of literature in the classroom through drama, story telling, book reporting, and choral speaking.  Education 536M concentrates on a pre-adolescent literature. 3 semester hours

name: Interdisc Teaching,MI
description: This course focuses on the developmental levels of the middle school student, appropriate instructional climates for middle grade classrooms, and interdisciplinary planning across subjects in English, History/Social Studies, Math, and Science. 3 semester hours

name: American Culture & Education
description: This course addresses cultural issues related to education. Topics include multicultural issues in America and the interpretation of demography in relation to schooling. The search for national identity and educational alternatives are explored. 3 semester hours

name: Classrm Mgt in Teaching Esl
description: This course focuses on classroom management as an effective tool for a positive learning environment.  Planning, implementing, and maintaining maangement procedures are discussed.

name: Theory & Methods of Teaching Esl
description: This course addresses the foundations of second language learning theory, research, and discourse in educational settings. It also focuses on strategies for teaching dual language instruction with emphasis on a culturally responsive environment and on legal issues as they apply to schooling for English language learners. 3 semester hours

name: Second Lang Acquisition
description: This course provides an overview of the major theories of first and second language acquisition. It applies these theories to classroom pedagogy and examines the influences of parents, siblings, and peers, as well as aspects of formal and informal education. It also examines the influence of region, culture, class, and gender on language acquisition; legal and ethical issues relative to language competency are addressed. 3 semester hours

name: Engl Lang & Lit TESOL
description: The purpose of this course is to give prospective teachers of English as a Second Language(ESL) a rich knowledge of literature with potential classroom applications for multicultural settings. Selection and analysis of language processes and literature for elementary and secondary-level classrooms are included. 3 semester hours

name: Appl Linguistics for Tchrs
description: This course acquaints teachers with the major analytical frameworks in linguistics. It surveys the discipline of linguistics, the study of human languages, contrastive features, and language systems. 3 semester hours

name: Supv/Obvsd Tchng Elem
description: This is a full-time field experience in a selected elementary school. This meets requirements of Connecticut's TEAM program. PRAXIS I must be passed. Department permission is required. 6 semester hours

name: Supv/Obsvd Tchg Sec Sch
description: This is a full-time field experience in a selected secondary schools. This meets requirements of Connecticut's TEAM program. PRAXIS I must be passed. Department permission is required. 6 semester hours

name: Supv/Obs Tchg Middle Sch
description: This is a full-time field experience in a selected middle school. This meets requirements of Connecticut's TEAM program. PRAXIS I must be passed. Department permission is required. 6 semester hours

name: Curriculum Development
description: This is a study and development of models for curriculum design and implementation at all levels of schooling. Emphasis is placed on current research and practice relevant to curriculum design and the planning and monitoring of curriculum plans in educational settings. Such topics as: curriculum assumptions, goals and objectives, knowledge and content, curriculum evaluation, implementation and staff development strategies are examined. 3 semester hours

name: Evaluation of Instructional Outcomes
description: This course gives students an orientation to the topics, issues, and concepts in the field of educational testing and measurement. Topics include methods for evaluating instructional programs, types of instruments for collecting data, and a variety of standardized, criterion-referenced, and performance-based assessments. The construction of teacher-made tests and the interpretation of different types of test scores are included. 3 semester hours

name: Human Development
description: This course provides an opportunity for the study of the subject matter of human development, with a concentration upon the uniqueness of the adolescent period. Theoretical models and methods of researching human growth and development including cognition, physical, social, emotional and moral development will be studied. Genetic and environmental influences of human development will be discussed. Implications for classroom instruction in the middle grades will be explored. 3 semester hours

name: Human Grwth/Dev
description: This course provides an opportunity for the study of the subject matter of human development, with a concentration upon the uniqueness of the adolescent period. Theoretical models and methods of researching human growth and development including cognition, physical, social, emotional and moral development will be studied. Genetic and environmental influences of human development will be discussed. Implications for classroom instruction in the middle grades will be explored. 3 semester hours

name: Educating Students With Exceptionalities
description: The focus of this course is placed upon the instructional methods and materials for exceptional students. General management techniques and administrative procedures are considered in light of the student?s special needs in order to identify and work effectively with the major categories of exceptionality, including the learning disabled, the handicapped, and the gifted, etc. Requirements of the 94-142 law are examined. 3 semester hours

name: Contemporary Problem Education I
description: This is a study of foundations, issues and contemporary trends in education with their application to teaching in the schools. An effort will be made to encourage teachers to develop an understanding of their own philosophy of education and how it affects their teaching. 3 semester hours

name: Comtemporary Problems II
description: This independent study fulfills the Final Degree Option for the Master?s degree. Students pursue an individually planned project under advisement of a faculty member. Extensive reading supports the project. May be taken as an extension of ED 500 or ED 565. 3-6 semester hours

name: Studies in Literacy Research
description: Students will research assigned or self-selected reseach topics in literacy education that are relevant to the work of literacy specialists. This course may be used to fulfill the Final Degree Option of a Masters in Science for the Remedial Reading and Remedial Language Arts Degree or those completing work in other educational courses.

name: Reading Diagnosis:intervention
description: This course examines the range of problems that cause students difficulties in literacy processes. It examines assessment instruments and strategies for intervention and instruction in Reading and Language Arts. 3 semester hours

name: Adv Diagn RLA Difficulties
description: This course is for students interested in working with learners experiencing profound difficulty in reading, writing, and other literacy processes. Students learn strategies for assessing students referred for specific literacy instruction. Both individual and group diagnostic assessments are used. Students learn how to interpret testing results and make recommendations for improvement. Prerequisite: EDUC 571 2 semester hours

name: Early Childhood Literacy
description: This course concentrates on the theories, instructional applications, and materials for the teaching, learning, and assessment of literacy processes in early childhood and up to grade 2. Topics include emergent literacy, phonological awareness, and phonic knowledge and instruction. 1 semester hour

name: Early Childhood Literacy
description: Participants will learn how to assess and teach the objectives in the Reading: Foundational Skills module of the English Language Arts Common Core State Standards K-12. This  includes concepts of print, phonological awareness, word identification, spelling and fluency.

name: Early Childhood Literacy
description: This course concentrates on the theories, instructional applications, and materials for the teaching, learning, and assessment of literacy processes in early childhood and up to grade 2. Topics include emergent literacy, phonological awareness, and phonic knowledge and instruction. 1 semester hour

name: Developmental Reading, Elementary
description: This course focuses on the theories, instructional applications, and materials for the teaching, learning, and assessment of literacy processes in elementary classrooms. Topics include strategies in word recognition, vocabulary development, and comprehension. The developmental needs of beginning readers are emphasized. 3 semester hours

name: Reading Content Area,Sec
description: This course focuses on the teaching and learning of comprehension and composing processes and strategies for content area disciplines. Critical reading and study strategies for expository text materials are emphasized. EDUC 575J concentrates on the comprehension and composing processes of students in secondary-level settings, grades 7-12. 3 semester hours

name: Reading Content,Middle
description: This course focuses on the teaching and learning of comprehension and composing processes and strategies for content area disciplines. Critical reading and study strategies for expository text materials are emphasized. EDUC 575M concentrates on appropriate materials, strategies, and assessments for reading and writing in middle grade settings, 4-8. 3 semester hours

name: Dev Reading, Mid
description: This course focuses on the theories, instructional applications, and materials for the teaching, learning, and assessment of reading and related literacy processes in middle grade (4-8) classrooms. 3 semester hours

name: Special Problems-Elementary Education
description: This is intended for students interested in independent study or research of a selected topic or problem in consultation with a faculty member. By arrangement. Faculty permission required. 1-6 semester hours

name: Special Problems-Secondary Education
description: This is intended for students interested in independent study or research of a selected topic or problem in consulting with a faculty member. By arrangement. Faculty permission required. 1-6 semester hours

name: Software Eval
description: This is designed to have students develop software evaluation criteria for the purpose of evaluating published computer programs. The student will have an opportunity to review educational programs. 1-3 semester hours

name: Technology Literacy for Educators
description: This course focuses on current instructional and educational technologies and ways to sue them in 21st classrooms. Students leave this class equipped with practical skills in multiple computer applications, web 2.0 technologies, and the confidence to embed these technologies into their K-12 classrooms. In addition, this course introduces students to technologies used by persons with exceptionalities to meet the needs of all students.

name: New Technologies for Learning
description: This course covers creation of learning objects, including text, raster/vector graphics, animations, slideshows, conferencing components, and videos for instructional Webs. There will be use of digital image capture equipment, including digital cameras, camcorders, and scanners. It also covers basic HTML, PDF  and OCR.  The final project will be an integration of elements into an instructional Web.

name: Thesis Rsch-Master's
description: This is a culminating experience option at the Master?s level for Education students. 2-6 semester hours

name: Literacy Research Project- th Year
description: Students will research assigned or self-selected reseach topics in literacy education to fulfill the Final Degree Option of a Sixth Year Degree for the Reading Language Arts Consultant Program, for the Remedial Reading and Remedial Language Arts Program, or other Sixth Year (Certificate of Advanced Study, CAS) degrees.

name: The Long Island Sound
description: The course focuses on marine biology, with particular attention to the eco-physiology of the Long Island Sound.

name: Planet Earth
description: The course focuses on advanced topics from earth science.

name: STEM for Educators
description: The course focuses on the mathematics, biology, and engineering aspects of signal processing.

name: The Nature of Science
description: The course focuses on important aspects from the history and philosophy of science.

name: Creating Caring Classroom Relationships
description: "Creating Caring Classroom Relationships To  Improve Social Emotional Student Learning"   Description: Nurturing a student's emotional and  social well-being where teachers are skilled in  leading with their heart will create a positive  classroom climate which will support both student  intellectual growth and life skills such as   self-management, self-awareness, responsible  decision making, social awareness and  relationship skills.

name: Gamify Your Classroom
description: Game   mechanics   aren't   just   used   in    video   games.   The   Girl/Boy   Scouts   and    the   armed   forces   have   always used    badges   and   ranks   to   motivate.    Businesses   use   gamification   to   train    employees   and   encourage customer   loyalty.    Fitness   trainers   are   using   it   with    clients   to   set   goals.   And   now   K-grad    classrooms   are embracing   gamification    techniques   in   increasing   numbers.   In this  class you will learn   how   to   apply   game    mechanics   to   your   own   Google   (or    actual)   classroom   in   any subject   area.

name: Effective Planning and Instruction
description: This course focuses on high leverage planning and instructional strategies for effective teaching. An overview of the requirements for the clinical practice portfolio in resident teaching is included.

name: No Room For Bullying
description: See and hear what may be going on beneath the surface right in front of you.  Establish a bully free zone in your classes.  Establish positive relationships, respect and tolerance.  Students can't learn in a stressful environment and worse than that, they devalue themselves.  Gain the skills to make a difference in your room, school and in a child's life. This class will meet on-line Friday and at the Stamford Center on Saturday.

name: Elem Math Common Core Standards of Nur
Dev & Design Blended Learning
description: Students will learn how to implement blended learning methods.  There will be a focus on practical applications and frameworks to enhance the blended learning environment.  Along with discussion of the possible challenges of this kind of implementation.

name: Content Review in Elem Liter
description: This course is designed to prepare participants for the Connecticut Foundation of Reading and the Praxis II Reading and Language Arts tests.  This course reviews content from EDUC 573, EDUC 574, and EDUC 440C including Concepts of Print, Phonological Awareness, Phonics, Fluency, Vocabulary, Comprehension, Language in Writing, and Communication Skills of Speaking, Listening and Viewing.

name: Interactive Read/Balanced Literacy
description: Interactive Read-Alouds This mod-map invites participants to review the best in children's literature (old classics and new tides) and through the use of critical literacy lens', interactive read-aloud plans will be created.  The read-aloud plans invite students to grapple, ponder and debate, building student discourse and perspectives.

name: Principles of Early Childhood Educ
description: This course is designed as an overview of early childhood care and education, including the basic values, structure, organization and programming used in early childhood learning. Students will gain knowledge and understanding of the theoretical and practical aspects of working with children from birth to age four and how to use that knowledge to create healthy, respectful, supportive and challenging learning environments.

name: Questions to Focus Learning
description: Many school systems are using essential questions as part of a reform effort.  Students will learn how to develop, use, and evaluate the effectiveness of essential questions.  In addition students will learn how to apply these questions to daily classroom activities.

name: Family & Community Partnerships in Ece
description: This course provides students with an understanding of how valuable working with families and communities are to a successful early childhood education program. How to create respectful, reciprocal relationships with both the families and community agencies that enhance the child's development and early learning will be stressed

name: Topics: African Amer History
description: In short, the course aims to critically examine African Americans during the 20th century. We will examine the charismatic leaders of the 20th as well as the everyday ordinary folks who constitute the bottom up masses who struggled over the course of the century to achieve equity within American society. Given the current events that are dominating headlines, which deals with the issue of race, gender and class, this course will ask the following questions: What are the historical roots of inequality? How do we define agency of marginal groups? Is the black freedom struggle ongoing? Have we achieved a post racial society?

name: Character Education
description: Review strategies for K-12 teachers to develop positive student character through instructional and management techniques. Participants are introduced to a comprehensive model for modern character education, provided opportunities to experience character ed. activities and investigate current resources. A syllabus is available via email. In addition, a copy of the course notes must be obtained prior to class, either by downloading from Class UB Blackboard or by purchasing from the instructor:

name: Supporting Families/Children W/Disabilit
description: Teachers are specifically trained to understand and teach students with special needs. Forming partnerships with families of students with challenges is the best way to advocate for universal access to educational services for students in need. Learn the most successful approaches to foster family involvement and positive parent-teacher relationships. This class will meet on-line Friday and at the Stamford Center on Saturday.

name: Critters in the Classroom
description: How many situations can you think of in which animal critters benefit individuals?  The classroom is another!    Pets within the classroom environment promote an emotionally safe student learning environment and cultivate responsibility, teamwork, compassion and respect for differences as well as kindness.  They also have been used successfully for decreasing anxiety in potentially stressful situations and providing learning opportunities for interdisciplinary approaches that will aid with Next Generation Science Standards. Join us in exploring all of these and implementing specific strategies that will benefit your learning environment!

name: Digital Teaching Portfolios
description: In this course students will focus on developing a digital teaching portfolio.  Students will affirm their teaching philosophy.  Students will learn which items to include in their portfolio based on their teaching domain.  There will be a focus on understanding the purpose of and audience for the portfolio.

name: Dvlpmtlly Appropriate Ece Classrooms
description: This course presents the key processes involved in the planning, implementation and evaluation of developmentally appropriate practices (DAP) in early childhood education. Main emphasis is on how developmentally appropriate practices translate into everyday decisions and actions found in early childhood classrooms.

name: The Teenage Brain
description: This seminar will introduce the student to current research about the neurological development of the teenage brain and how this influences their decision-making. Participants will learn some effective instructional strategies, social-emotional coping, and parental involvement guidelines.  1 credit

name: Teaching Shakespeare
description: The name Shakespeare conjures fear in the hearts  of students and teachers  alike. From a student's  perspective, the plays of Shakespeare are  difficult and dense. From a teacher's point of  view, the material is challenging to make  interesting and understandable. The purpose of  this course is to explore methods of making  Shakespeare less intimidating and hopefully a joy  to teach and learn. Our focus will be on  strategies that will give students 'ownership' of  the text.

name: Instructional Strategies for Teaching de
description: Instructional Strategies for Teaching Decimals and  Fractions to Elementary Students  This course will focus on instructional strategies  to effectively teach fractions and decimals to  students in Grades 3-5.  There will be an  emphasis on utilizing the  Concrete-Representational-Abstract (C-R-A)  approach to instruction and how it aligns to the  Connecticut Core Standards and the Standards for  Mathematical Practice.  Time will also be spent  the Three-Part Problem Solving Plan used in  rigorous real-world problems.

name: Connecticut History
description: The history of a place is more than just a  collection of dates and names - it is a hundred  thousand interconnected stories of people who  live there. In this class we will learn about  Connecticut, whose citizens have become some of  the most important and interesting Americans. But  even this limited history is practically endless,  with dozens of stories in every town, in every  family. So, by focusing on a small, yet  fascinating place we will hopefully find an  appreciation for the depth and breadth of history  itself. We will also focus on the way that this  history can be integrated into various classroom  settings, in order to link our students to the  place they live.

name: Urban Education
description: Understanding the urban student can be very difficult for educators in the 21st century. Values, attitudes and communication styles are vastly different from students raised in a middle class suburban environment.  This course will discuss how teachers can begin to understand the psychological, social, economic and environmental influences affecting students in urban education today.

name: Content Review for Science
description: This course is designed to offer broad knowledge and competencies in Earth, Life and Physical sciences. It focuses on fundamental scientific concepts, principles, and interrelationships within the content of real-world, meaningful scientific phenomena, problems and issues. It focuses on basic understanding of Earth, life processes, and physical matter and energy. Additionally, an understanding of the nature of science as a complex human enterprise with a distinct philosophy and methodology and a place and role in the society, is crucial. This course helps its participants relate to physical, earth, and life science concepts through discussions, and question-and-answer sessions.

name: STEM for Teacher Educators
description: The course focuses on the mathematics, biology, and engineering aspects of signal processing.

name: Bloom's Taxonomy & Creative Classroom
description: Bloom's Taxonomy accounts for the traditional learning methods occurring in our practicing classrooms, through behaviors and actions. Today's learners process information differently than any other generation. By integrating Bloom's Digital Taxonomy we can facilitate learning using methods which will increase the competence and quality of student work. Let's explore ideas of project and problem based learning using all levels of Blooms.

name: Secondary Social Studies Praxis II Prep
description: This course is designed for you to pass the Praxis II Social Studies: Content Knowledge exam. The course will provide you with a comprehensive overview and increase your odds of success on this standardized test: review all key content areas, learn test strategies, and implement a study plan.  This is an essential course for all secondary social studies majors.

name: Total Participation Techniques
description: The course would include an understanding of the  research supporting student engagement with  diverse/inclusive environments.    A toolbox of  engagement techniques would be made during the  class and students would plan a short 10 minute  lesson to demonstrate using techniques.   The  course will include all grade levels, K-12.

name: Athletic Directorship
description: The correct training and education in order to become a high school athletic director is the foundation of this seminar.  This course will start at the beginning with strategies for interviewing and securing the position in this competitive arena.  From there we will cover effective teaching strategies to mentor  and manage different types of coaches in the wide scope of high school athletic departments.  The basic daily administrative functions and overall responsibilities encompassing each coaching season will also be addressed.

name: Strat for Program Development in Ece
description: Students will examine the necessary skills and professional competencies needed to be effective early childhood program managers. Topics include: organizational vision and mission, objectives and functions of staff supervision, guidelines for recruiting, hiring, and evaluating a diverse staff, team building, conflict resolution and effective management approaches.

name: Explore the Common Core
description: Common Core State Standards is a hot topic for everyone in the education community.  Explore the organization, key components and practical strategies for teaching and learning with the Common Core. Come away with resources that will help you in your real life. This class will meet on-line Friday and at the Stamford Center on Saturday.

name: Character Study
description: A Character Study Using strong children's literature and mini-lessons that stick, participants will learn how to build students understanding of character through questioning, partnership work, jotting and writing long.  Participants will develop mini-lessons that are specific to their individual grade-levels.

name: Data Driven School Practice
description: The NCLB Act places emphasis on using instructional practices that have provided evidence of their effectiveness through rigorous scientific research. This course provides pre-service teachers with the information they need to determine what is meant by evidence, the types of evidence that can be used to support educational change, and the issues that need to be addressed when educators adopt evidence-based practices in their classrooms.

name: Testing & Assessment Strategies in Educ
description: Tests and assessments are essential to effectively evaluate and enhance students' learning and teachers' instruction, conversely, they can confuse and alienate students, distort curriculum, and hinder good instruction. Results are used to improve instruction and hold schools accountable for quality of instruction. Test-based reform efforts have stirred much controversy and are causing educators to rethink assessment. Learn strategies to help you meet standards and understand the public pressures as well as instructional need for good assessment.

name: Curriculum Dev
description: This is a study and development of models for curriculum design and implementation at all levels of schooling. Emphasis is placed on current research and practice relevant to curriculum design and the planning and monitoring of curriculum plans in educational settings. Such topics as: curriculum assumptions, goals and objectives, knowledge and content, curriculum evaluation, implementation and staff development strategies are examined. 3 semester hours

name: Intro to Educational Leadership
description: This course will focus upon contemporary society and changing policy issues that confront managers and leaders of educational thought throughout the 21st Century. Seminal issues such as the impact of political forces upon federal, state, and local educational policies will be considered. Labor relations will be analyzed. Empowerment of teachers will be examined. 3 semester hours

name: Admin:Org & Staff Ed Inst
description: This course will focus upon contemporary society and changing policy issues that confront managers and leaders of educational thought throughout the 21st Century. Seminal issues such as the impact of political forces upon federal, state, and local educational policies will be considered. Labor relations will be analyzed. Empowerment of teachers will be examined. 3 semester hours

name: Org,Admin & Supv RDLA
description: This course focuses on the role of the Reading and Language Arts Consultant as an educational leader in schools and school districts and focuses on issues of organization, administration, and supervision of reading and language arts programs. Note: Students enrolled in this course must also concurrently enroll in EDLD 611 Administration: Organizing, and Staffing Educational Institutions. While EDLD 611 focuses on the broader issues of educational leadership in schools, EDLD 611A specifically focuses on reading and language arts programs and personnel. 1 semester hour

name: Contemp Educ Issues
description: This is an investigation of concepts, research findings, and practices focusing on the development and change of educational organizations in relation to relevant goals and objectives. Emphasis is placed on such areas as leadership theory and behavior, organizational climate, human relations and communications within the organization, and change strategies. Theoretical concepts of leadership are integrated along with practical applications. 3 semester hours

name: School Finance
description: This is a study of educational fiscal control including: budget preparation and presentation, accounting procedures, tax structures, analyses of costs, comparative data and auditing. Includes federal, state and local phases of support of educational systems. Special emphasis is given to New York and Connecticut fiscal patterns. 3 semester hours

name: School Law
description: This is a study of the legal basis for public education in the United States; a study of state and federal statutes providing for education. An examination is made of statutes, court decisions, and policies and practices arising out of these factors. The legal status of boards, teachers, administrators, pupils and parents is examined with special emphasis on New York and Connecticut. 3 semester hours

name: Eval School Effective
description: This course examines the various ways to evaluate the effectiveness of a school?s performance: student achievement, faculty performance, faculty morale, provision for diverse student needs and development of student emotional growth. The course examines how data can and should affect instructional issues. 3 semester hours

name: Supervision:Eval/Prof Dev
description: This is a study of concepts and strategies focusing on the evaluation of teachers and other educators for purposes of performance improvement and quality assurance. Emphasis will be placed on research findings, current practices, and the achievement of competency related to classroom observation and evaluation, the planning and implementation of professional development, and the creation of organizational climate and human relationships conducive to effective evaluation and professional growth of educators. 3 semester hours

name: Map It Forward: Curriculum Ldrshp
description: The course is designed to increase knowledge, understanding, and competencies required for researching and designing curriculum considering the needs of 21st century learners. Topics to be examined include: UDL, CBC, extended knowledge of the CCSS with additional focus on the NGSS and C-3 framework for social studies.

name: Spvs Prg Students w/Exceptionalities
description: The emphasis is on the administrative aspects of Special Education programs for schools. 3 semester hours

name: Urban Leadership
description: Offered by arrangement. 1-6 semester hours

name: Internship Educ Leadership
description: A cooperatively guided administrative experience in a school system. Pre-requisite: Completion of major portion of the requirements for the Sixth Year Professional Diploma and permission of major advisor. 3 semester hours

name: Spec Topics:Supervision
description: Special department offerings including workshops, conferences, institutes focusing on new developments in the field. 1-6 semester hours

name: Internship-RLA
description: This course is a cooperatively guided administrative experience in the area of literacy education for those desiring to be certified as Reading and Language Arts Consultants. The internship includes a series of practicum experiences in a variety of school settings and includes research in the area of literacy education. Students gain practical field based experience through a range of tasks and situations characteristic of the position of the Reading and Language Arts Consultant in school settings. 6 semester hours

name: Classroom Behavior Mgt for Educ and Admn
Continuing Doctoral Seminar
description: The seminar meets periodically during the academic year and for two full weeks each summer, for three consecutive summers. It provides opportunities for students to work with scholars and leaders from a variety of disciplines to broaden perspectives on educational leadership and to develop an intellectual style for dealing with educational problems. 6 semester hours per year

name: Program Dev and Curriculum Theory
description: EDLD 801 section A: Emphasis of this seminar is on a historical overview of curricula theory and the current research and practice relevant to curriculum design, planning and monitoring in educational settings. This course provides an introduction to conceptions of curriculum and their effects on pedagogy from a historical perspective, with particular emphasis on discerning and interpreting how social, cultural, and political circumstances shape educational practices.  EDLD 801 section B: The focus of this seminar is on professional development processes and applications. Topics to be examined include the following: understanding by design, concept-based professional development goals and objectives, needs assessment, implementation strategies, and evaluation techniques for conducting rigorous professional development designed to improve organizations and personnel.

name: Constitutional Law
description: Legal questions relating to personnel, students, community, religion, finance, school property, teacher organizations, equality of opportunity and other legal and political issues with which the educational leader must be familiar in order to be effective in decision-making and organizational development are investigated. Emphasis is placed on landmark judicial decisions, recent statutory developments, and constitutional background. Students will read, analyze, and interpret significant Supreme Court decisions regarding educational matters as well as pertinent lower federal and state court decisions. The principal of non-judicial remedies will be explored and the appeals process will be examined in detail.

name: Grant Writing, Procurement and Policy
description: EDLD 805 Section A: This seminar provides the background and experience in the grant writing process for major federal and state discretionary competitions and private funding agency grants.  EDLD 805 Section B: This seminar will focus on the preparation of proposals to National Science Foundation, the United States Department of Education (USDOE)-including Office of Special Education Programs (OSEP & OSERS), The Institute of Educational Science (IES), The United States Department of Health and Human Services (USDHHS), and the Connecticut State Education Department. Private foundations and organizations will also be considered for competitions that total $100,000 or more.

name: Q.A.& Eval Strat
description: This course considers current techniques for designing, implementing and analyzing projects in education and typical models for facilitating decision-making. The elements of personnel and program assessment within the contemporary educational system are included. Strategies focusing upon experiential learning and community contact are featured, and the student will be exposed to collection and analysis of real data and related computer simulation activities. Statistical and evaluative investigations are emphasized which are both fundamental and sufficiently sophisticated for advanced decision-making and leadership. This course is required. 6 semester hours

name: Quant Analy & Eval Strat
description: This course considers current techniques for designing, implementing and analyzing projects in education and typical models for facilitating decision-making. The elements of personnel and program assessment within the contemporary educational system are included. Strategies focusing upon experiential learning and community contact are featured, and the student will be exposed to collection and analysis of real data and related computer simulation activities. Statistical and evaluative investigations are emphasized which are both fundamental and sufficiently sophisticated for advanced decision-making and leadership. This course is required. 6 semester hours

name: Org Theories and Management
description: EDLD 807 Section A: The emphasis of this seminar is placed on leadership theories, organizational climate, human relations, and communication within organizations. The course covers a historical overview of organization and leadership theories and the culminating project is defining and defending a philosophy of leadership. EDLD 807 Section B: This seminar is designed for students in their first semester of the program to be introduced to the School of Education graduate faculty who will co-teach the course presenting their areas of expertise. This course provides the opportunity for students to be introduced to the faculty so that they can determine who might be applicable members of their dissertation committee.

name: Program Evaluation and Human Relations
description: EDLD 808 Section A: This seminar focuses on program evaluation techniques including multiple means of assessment that will be discussed and considered. Concepts such as reliability, validity, credibility, and authenticity will be explored as well as summative and formative data collection and analysis strategies. The program evaluation approach will be applied to authentic experiences and scenarios that focus on assessing and evaluating institutions, programs, teaching, and learning.  EDLD 808 Section B: This seminar focuses on the purposes, issues, and controversies surrounding human relations with emphasis on organization development and change theories. The process of strategic planning as a vehicle to improve organizational effectiveness through human relations will be emphasized

name: Intro Quant, Qual Methods Research
description: Introduction to Research is an overview course in research methodology and evaluation techniques relevant to the conduct of qualitative, quantitative, action, and mixed methods studies of leadership, curriculum, teaching, and learning. Fundamentals of, quantitative, qualitative, action and mixed methods research will be introduced from five prominent dimensions: leadership, curricula, program evaluation, teaching, and assessment.

name: Quantitative Research
description: One of the greatest challenges faced by school leaders is harnessing the power of data to drive school improvement.  To this end, in the present climate of rapidly emerging research findings and data-driven decision-making, today's leaders must be able to perform, analyze, and critically interpret statistics.  Hence, this course is designed to prepare doctoral students to perform dissertation research by giving them fundamental understanding of the quantitative research methodology.  Overall, this course will provide students with: (a) the fundamental of descriptive and inferential statistics necessary to manipulate quantitative information,(b)the necessary frameworks to describe, interpret, and critique the components of various quantitative research studies in education, and (c)the conceptual understanding of the experimental and non-experimental research methodologies.

name: Literature Review
description: Literature review EDLD 813 Section A is designed to be taken in the summer of the first year after students have taken introductory research and quantitative research methods in the program.  Conducting the literature review helps refine the student's topic, the dissertation proposal, and prepares students for writing the Human Subject approval application.  Literature review theory focuses on the theoretical assumptions associated with the dissertation topic. This course should be taken in the second year of the program after EDLD 813A Literature Review has been taken.

name: Qualitative Research and Evaluation Stra
description: Qualitative research and evaluative Strategies introduces students to theoretical, paradigmatic and methodological research perspectives associated with the qualitative tradition. Case studies, grounded theory, ethnographic, and narrative approaches will be presented in this class paying particular attention to interpretive, critical, and participatory research techniques, methodologies and methods. Qualitative evaluation techniques used in program evaluations will be emphasized.  EDLD 814 introduces students to practical research techniques including the development of semi structured and open ended interview questions, how to conduct, record and analyze interviews, and the use of field notes when collecting observation data.  Emphasis will be placed on understanding the ramifications of purposeful sampling, forms of credibility, the role of the researcher, and ethical dimensions associated with qualitative inquiry.

name: Mixed Methods Research
description: Mixed method research introduces students to mixed-method research in the social sciences. Students should have some familiarity with research (quantitative and/or qualitative) and the epistemological and ontological underpinnings of the two methods as well as a basic understanding of their educational or social science research topic. This course completes the process of the proposal preparation expanding methodological and procedural techniques used in dissertation process. Specific objectives for this course include: (a) the history and language of mixed method research in education/social sciences; (b) summarization of current issues related to the paradigm wars and where mixed-methods research currently fits into education/social sciences; (c) advance understanding of research issued in educational/social sciences through discussions about paradigmatic compatibility, the current standing of mixed-methods in academic and political field, and the process and design of mixed-method studies;(d) proposal writing strategies including for mixed-methods research;(e) data sampling, collection and analysis strategies including for mixed method research;(f) reflections about the role of the researcher and their worldview in a mixed methods design.

name: Action Research Project
description: The Action Research seminar is the second year summer project designed to help students understand how to conduct, evaluate and disseminate research. This culminating research projects starts after students have completed introduction to research (EDLD 811), quantitative (EDLD 812) qualitative (EDLD 814) and mixed method research (EDLD 815) in the second year of program. Conducting a case study or a collaborative action research project helps refine practical research skills, presentation techniques, and the ability to publish

name: Postsecondary Teaching
description: Post-secondary teaching provides students the opportunity to determine if working in higher education is preferred. This class is to be taken as a final class in the program course sequence. Repeatable up to 8 credits.

name: Doctoral Residency Hybrid Edd Intnl Educ
Culture, Society and Educ Internl Contex
Dissertation: Comprehensive Exam
description: During the third year of the program, students participate in this seminar in preparation for their 30 day, 3 question 45+ page comprehensive examination. Students should only take EDLD 845 after they have completed all of their courses or with the prior approval of their Chair.

name: Dissertation: Proposal Defense
description: During the third year of the program, students participate in this seminar which focus on the selection and development of a dissertation proposal. Students are ordinarily expected to complete the major portion of their work on the dissertation proposal prior to the conclusion of the formal part of the program

name: Continuous Dissertation
description: Individual research and advisement relative to a student's dissertation topic is the sine qua non of this course. Doctoral candidates are expected to register for Continuous Dissertation 850 every semester (Fall, Spring and Summer) until their dissertations have received final approval. Prerequisite: Successful completion of EDLD 845 Dissertation Proposal and EDLD 846 Comprehensive Examination. 0 semester hours

name: Special Education for Administrators
description: Supervision of Programs & Services for Stu dents with Exceptionalities. This course is designed to prepare school ad ministrators with the skills to supervise and implement appropriate services for students in need of response to intervention services Educational Leadership 312 and/or programs for students identified as in need of special education services. An emphasis is on service delivery models, due process procedures and supervision of specialists responsible for providing services to identified students. 3 semester hours

name: Administrative Internship
description: EDLD 800D Continuing Doctorial Seminars meet the nine credit residency requirement designated at the inception of the program.Seminar topics are designed to help prepare doctoral students for the comprehensive examination, dissertation research process, and specific concepts related to students intrests in the Education Leadership Program. EDLD 818a Adminstrative Leadership Experience required for 092 Certifucation in the State of Connecticut. this class should to be taken in conjuction with or after EDLD 816 Action Research Project in the second or third summer of program.

name: Engineering Mathematics W/App
description: Course Description: _ This course provides a foundation in mathematical principles with applications in - engineering. It reviews functions, limit, derivatives, and integration and covers a broad spectrum of mathematical techniques important to the solution of engineering problems. Topics include ordinary and partial differential equations, power series, parametric and polar curves, vectors and matrices, linear algebra, the Laplace transform, the z transform, the Fourier series. Application of these topic to the solution of engineering problems is stressed.

name: Digital Design I
description: Basic digital design principles. Boolean algebra. Combinational logic design with gates, MSI, LSI. Sequential logic design; register, counters, memory and programmable logic. Prerequisite: Mathematical sophistication. 3 semester hours

name: Network Analysis I
description: DC circuits, mesh, node voltages, superposition. Steady-state AC, read/imaginary power. Bode plots, Ideal op-amp circuit analysis. Pre-requisite: Math 110 3 semester hours

name: Network Analyis II
description: Transient analysis of 1-pole and 2-ple circuits using differential equations and Laplace transforms. Fourier series derivation and application to electric circuits. Comparison of Fourier transform to Laplace transform. Pre-requisite: Electrical Engineering 233 2 semester hours

name: Network Analysis I Lab
description: Use of resistor networks and DC voltage sources in various configurations; measurements of current flow and voltage difference. Introduction to RLC circuits in steady AC conditions. Familiarization with standard laboratory instruments. Co-requisite: Electrical Engineering 233 1 three-hour laboratory, 1 semester hour

name: Network Analy II Lab
description: Steady state and transient analysis of RLC circuits. Typical series and parallel resonance circuits are examined and their parameters experimentally determined; two pole network analysis; transformers; frequency response plots. Extensive use of the oscilloscope. Pre-requisite: Electrical Engineering 235, Co-requisite: Electrical Engineering 234. 1 three-hour laboratory, 1 semester hour

name: Intro to Microprocessor
description: Theory and application of microprocessors, and associated peripheral devices such as memory, ports, clocks, system design and debugging techniques, including specific design problems using existing devices. Programming aids, including assemblers and simulators. Programming problems including peripheral device service routines and arithmetic operations. Information structures for real-time data acquisition systems. Prerequisite: Computer Engineering 210 and Computer Science 102. 3 lecture hours; 1 three-hour laboratory; 3 semester hours

name: Econ&Mgmt Engr Projects
description: The design process, engineering economics, project planning and ethics in engineering practice. A required course for all Computer Science majors, normally taken in the junior year, offered both semesters. Prerequisite: Computer Science 102, 102a, Math 215, Physics 112 and junior standing. 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Fiber Optics
description: Communication via light waves over fiber optics cables. Analysis of light emission and light detection. Absorption loss. Optical devices, connectors, splices and Local Area Network (LANs). Pre-requisite: Physics 112 or equivalent. 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Fiber Optics Lab
description: Communication via light waves over fiber optics cables. Analysis of light emission and light detection. Absorption loss. Optical devices, connectors, splices and Local Area Networks (LANs). Pre-requisite: Physics 112 or equivalent. 3 lecture hours; 3 semester hours

name: Controls
description: Analysis of steady state and transient response of control systems. Laplace transforms methods. Transfer functions.Stability criteria. Nyquist, Bode and root locus methods. System stabilization, System Design.

name: Signals and Systems
description: Students learn to analyze theoretically and by computer both continuous and discrete signals and the application of each to realworld problems. Applications involve the definition of a system, defined either by a laplace or z-transform and the output of same to the application of any input signal.

name: Digital Design II With Laboratory
description: esign of complex digital systems; top-down design and modularization. Implementation of controllers. Use of hardware design languages (VHDL) to implement systems. Rapid prototyping. Fault tolerant design. Prerequisite: Computer Engineering 210. Laboratory includes implementation of digital systems using FPGAs. 3 lecture hours; 4 semester hours; 1 three hour laboratory

name: Analog Electronic Lab I
description: This is a hands-on analog circuit design lab. You will combine integrated circuits and discrete electronic components to design practical analog circuits for day-to-day industry use.

name: Analog Electronics Lab II
description: This course focuses on designing of BJT's and FET's amplifiers. Students focus on design parameters such as gain, frequency response and matching impedance. Students develop in-depth understanding of theory of electronic devices and circuits through practical experiments.

name: Field Theory
description: The course covers fundamental concepts of RF circuit design. Students will learn circuit level design of high speed analog/RF circuits. Specific topics include impact of scaling and noise in high-speed communication circuits, low noise amplifiers, mixers, power amplifiers and frequency synthesizers. 3 lecture hours; 3 semester hours

name: Modern Communication Systems
description: Eleg 342 is the first course on communications within the Electrical Engineering program.  The objective of the course is to familiarize undergraduate students to the fundamentals of modern digital and analog communications systems.  3cr. Pre-Req: eleg 234

name: Digital Signal Proc I
description: Basic digital design principles. Boolean algebra. Combinational logic design with gates, MSI, LSI. Sequential logic design; register, counters, memory and programmable logic. Prerequisite: Mathematical sophistication. 3 semester hours

name: MEMS
description: MEMS (Microelectromechanical systems ) refers to devices and system with very small size in the range of microns. It is one of the most important high technologies developed in 20th century. This course covers the fundamentals of MEMS. It includes the introduction to MEMS, basic microfabrication techniques, MEMS materials and their properties, MEMS device design and simulation, working principle analysis, MEMS device fabrication sequence, MEMS packaging and assembly, signal testing, MEMS applications (inertial MEMS, MOEMS, BioMEMS, RFMEMS, etc ) 3 credit hours

name: Electronics
description: Application of diodes, bipolar transistors (BJT) and field effect transistors (FET) to signal amplification and switching. Computer Simulation. Pre-requisite: ELEG 233, Pre-requisite: ELEG 235. 3 semester hours; 3 semester hours

name: Senior Project
description: Student work for approximately 150 hours performing research work within the department of Electrical Engineering. Emphasis is on good technical writing and imaginative design of solutions to a given problem.

name: Senior Design Project
description: Student work for approximately 150 hours performing research work within the department of Electrical Engineering. Emphasis is on good technical writing and imaginative design of solutions to a given problem.

name: Senior Design Project
description: Continuation of Design Project

name: Communications Lab
description: Hands-on experience with digital and analog communication equipment, AM, FM and digital modulation techniques. Design and test of optimal configuration. Measurement of performance parameters in the presence of thermal noise. Pre-requisite: Electrical engineering 441.   3 Semester hours

name: Modern Communications
description: The course teaches the undergraduate student the fundamentals of both analog and digital communications, and it shows how analog technology is used to produce modern systems for the transmission of digital data.

name: Controls Lab
description: Laboratory study of feedback control systems with experiments analyzing different types of plants, transducers and control techniques, emphasis on real-time computer control.

name: Programmable Logic Control
description: This course will start with the basics of Boolean Algebra; it will cite the differences between PLC control and relay control and full automation of major machines and appliances; the differences in these controls will show how hard relay control is to implement and how flexible PLC control actually is; many different math functions will be analyzed and implemented in the theoretical construction of fully functioning PLC. 3 lecture hours, 3 semester

name: Digital Integrated Ckts Desn
description: Several integrated circuit architectures are analyzed at the transmitter level to find key parameters by hand analysis as well as computer simulation: rise time, fall time, noise margins, logic state, hysteresis/memory, fanout, and power dissipation. Analysis includes an analysis of the major logic families: TTL,CMOS, NMOS, ECL, PECL, differential logic. 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Analog Intg Ckt Desn
description: Do a complete analysis of the 741 op-amp, including bandwidth, gain analysis, slew rate, power efficiency and I/O impedances. Analyze ROM, Ram, TTL, ECL, CMOS and more modern logic structures including Fanout, noise margin, latching, contention, logic and delay response. Pre-requisite: Electrical Engineering 348 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Ind Study
description: Independent study of advanced topics in Electrical Engineering. Problem assignment to be arranged with and appproved by the department.

name: RF VLSI
description: The course covers fundamental concepts of RF circuit design. Students will learn circuit level design of high speed analog/RF circuits. Specific topics include impact of scaling and noise in high-speed communication circuits, low noise amplifiers, mixers, power amplifiers and frequency synthesizers. 3 lecture hours; 3 semester hours

name: Digital VLSI
description: The objective of this course is to teach students the CMOS transistor design in VLSI circuits. (CMOS stands for complementary metal oxide semiconductor.) Supported by CAD tools, students will learn gate level design, IC design, fabrication, and layout of digital CMOS integrated circuits. With these skills, students will also be able to interact with integrated circuit fabrication process engineers after completing this course. 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Random Signal Processing
description: Change the name to Random Signal Processing. Topics in the course Statistics for Engineers and Random Signal Processing are the same. However, Random Signal Processing is a better title, since it pertains to modern applications of statistics for Engineers in the real-world.

name: Soft Computing I
description: Modeling and solving engineering problems using computational methods. Topics include exact (provable) methods ( linear and convex programming) and fast methods ( heuristic search, genetic algorithm, neural networks, etc ) 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Fuzzy Logic Systems
description: A study of fuzzy set theory and applications. Topics include (a) fundamental concepts of fuzzy logic, (b) fuzzy sets, (c)fuzzy model identification, (d) neuro-fuzzy systems, (e) fuzzy logic in control engineering, and (f) fuzzy logic in pattern recognition and artifical intelligence.

name: Numerical Analysis
description: This course is done on the computer using the package Matlab. Course includes mathematical modeling, solutions to one or more linear systems of equations (including Gaussian elimination, iteration, Newton's method, and secant method), simple interpolation and spline interpolation, finding values of exact integrals (Romberg and Gaussian quadrature), solution of ordinary differential equations (Euler and Runge-Kutta), and the solution of partial differential equations.

name: Data Acq & Virtual Instr Lab
description: This is an introductory lab for the real-time data acquisition and instrument controls. The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the field of data communication between the computers and instruments with experiments. These experiments cover the LabView programming for the interface to communicate with different instruments or data acquisition boards through GPIB, RS232, and USB cables. After the students complete this course, they are expected to be able to set up their own systems for different testing and controls.

name: Bio-Sensors
description: This course will provide an interview of biosensors, including their use in Pharmaceutical research, diagnostic testing, and policing the environment. Topics include the sensitivity resolution, selectivity, dynamic range, and noise of biosensor. Other topics covered include transducer phenomenology, biosensor structure, and sensor performance. 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Plc Solutions in Industrial Applications
description: This course builds on PLC's (ELEG 464) by using sensors (both thermal sensors, motion sensors, and camera input) to control the automation process; topics in servo motors, variable frequency drives, and HMI (human machine interaction) and touch screens are also introduced both in theory and in a lab setting. 3 lecture hours; 3 semester hours

name: Bioelectronics
description: Discipline of biomedical Engineering has emerged due to integration of engineering principles and technology into medicine. This course is intended for engineers and engineering students interested in persuing career in biomedical engineering and health related filed. This copurse will first introduction Applications of electrical engineering principles to biology, medicine, behavior, or health will be identified during first half of the semester. Second half of the course will focus on research, design, development and application of biosensors and Bioelectronics.

name: Bioinformatics
description: The course covers algorithmic aspects of modern DNA and protein analysis. Topics include: (i) Reviews of DNA, RNA and Proteins, (ii) Genome rearrangements, (iii) Sequence Alignment and fast algorithms (BLAST), (IV) Genome expressions and DNA-microarray, (v) Phylogenic trees, (vi) Protein docking and drug discovery, etc 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Laser Applications
description: Course studies (i) fundamentals of laser operation and the types of laser operation, (ii) laser applications in spectroscopy and photochemistry, (iii) laser applications in dentistry and eye surgery (LASIK), and (iv) laser applications in bar code readers and welding/cutting.

name: Fiber Optics
description: Communication via light waves over fiber optics cables. Analysis of light emission and light detection. Absorption loss. Optical devices, connectors, splices and Local Area Network (LANs). Pre-requisite: Physics 112 or equivalent. 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Fiber Optics Lab
description: Communication via light waves over fiber optics cables. Analysis of light emission and light detection. Absorption loss. Optical devices, connectors, splices and Local Area Networks (LANs). Pre-requisite: Physics 112 or equivalent. 3 lecture hours; 3 semester hours

name: Modern Electronics
description: Application of diodes, bipolar transistors (BJT) and field effect transistors (FET) to signal amplification and switching. Computer Simulation. Pre-requisite: ELEG 233, Pre-requisite: ELEG 235. 3 semester hours; 3 semester hours

name: Modern Wireless Comm
description: Evolution of Mobile Radio Communications to cell phones and personal communications: 2nd and 3rd and 4th generation. Concepts include cell fundamentals, path loss, fading, ghosts, modulation techniques, equalization, speech coding and networks. 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Satellite Communications
description: Detailing concepts and calculations from the entire field is enough to permit the kinds of analysis needed for major systems planning decisions. This course covers channel capacity, picture quality, signal to noise ratio, bit error rate, earth station antenna size and offers new materials on orbital mechanics and geometry. Pre-requisites: Electrical Engineering 441 or equivalent 3 semester hours

name: Field Theory
description: The course covers fundamental concepts of RF circuit design. Students will learn circuit level design of high speed analog/RF circuits. Specific topics include impact of scaling and noise in high-speed communication circuits, low noise amplifiers, mixers, power amplifiers and frequency synthesizers. 3 lecture hours; 3 semester hours

name: Data Acquisition Virtual Instrument Lab
description: Data acquisition is an important skill for electrical/electronic engineers to have and virtual instrumentation is powerful for the system simulation and hardware controls.  The lab experiments cover the technologies in LabVIEW program development, instrument interfacing, and networking.

name: Power Electronics Lab
description: Power Electronics as an enabling technology are widely used in applications such as flexible production systems, energy conservation, renewable energy, transportation etc.  This lab is an introduction to switched-mode power converters.  It provides a basic knowledge of circuitry for the control and conversion of electrical power.  These converters can change and regulate the voltyage, current, or power; dc-dc converters, ac-dc rectifiers, and dc-ac inverters.

name: Power System Protection and Relaying
description: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and fundamentals of the electric power system protection and relaying. It teaches the methodology to model the different electric component of the power system such as bus bars, generators, motors, transmission lines, and transformers. Also, it analyzes the different types of symmetrical and asymmetrical short circuit faults along with the different protection schemes used to protect the power system component. It presents the philosophy of protecting the power systems and discusses the fundamental relay operating principles and characteristics. It explores the different types of relays and measuring instruments. Finally, it introduces practical techniques/applications and relaying systems used to protect real-life transmission and distribution systems/components.

name: Power System Protection & Relaying
description: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and fundamentals of the electric power system's protection and relaying. It teaches methadology to model the different electric components of the power system such as bus bars, generators, motors, transmission lines, and transformers. Also, it analyzes the different types of symmetrical and asymmetrical short circuit faults along with the different protection schemes used to protect the power system. It presents the philosophy of protection and discusses the fundamentals of relays. Finally, it introduces practical techniques/applications and relaying systems used to protect real-life transmission and distribution systems/comnponents.

name: Electric Machines
description: The course introduces the laws of electricity and magnetism and prinipals of transformers applicable to electric machine construction.  Machines studied include DC motors, AC induction motors, synchronous motors, stepper motors, relays, and motor/generators.  Both single phase and 3-phase motors are analyzed for their efficiency, speef, and mechanical stability.  The state of the art VFD (Variable frequency drive) is shown to be the best way to improve efficiency and produce the maximum torque and speed control for any given motor.

name: Adv Power Analysis
description: The course provides the next level of expertise Power Systems and Design.  It includes (i) the modeling of a systems symmetrical and unsymmetrical faults, (ii) the means to protect a system and its components, (iii) the control of power systems, and (iv) the analysis of power systems' transient operation and behavior.

name: Microwaves
description: Passive and Active elements for the generation, modulation, amplification and reception of microwaves. Radar and other microwaves systems. Pre-requisites: Field Theory 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Radar Thry & Sim
description: Radar Fundamentals, Radar Cross section, Types of Radars, Radar Detection, Waveform Analysis, SNR, Compression and Wave Propagation. Target Indicator and Tracking. The course will include extensive use of MATLAB for programming and simulation. 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Power Syst Distribu
description: A comprehensive study of modeling of the distribution of power system components and planning, including load characteristics, application of power transformers, design of transmission lines, distribution sub-stations, primary systems and secondary systems, voltage drop and power less calculations, application of capacitors, harmonics on distribution systems, voltage regulation, fault calculation and protection.

name: RF Communications
description: Special analysis; modulation and demodulation system analysis, including AM, FM, pulse modulation and transmission of digital information. Signal design and system considerations. Pre-requisite: Electrical Engineering 234 3 semester hours

name: Digital Communications
description: Detection of noise in thermal noise. Digital sequences. Optimal filtering and statistical decision theory. Optimum receiver design criteria. Performance, configuration and trade-offs. Pre-requisite: Electrical Engineering 441 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Digital Signal Proc I
description: The FFT Spectral Analysis, Filtering in the presence of noise. Correlation. Introduction to stochastic signal processing. Computer projects. Pre-requisite: Electrical Engineering 234 or equivalent 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Power Electronics
description: Application of power diodes and power transistors in rectifier arrangements and voltage regulators. Properties and application in power converters, inverters and motor drives. Pre-requisite: Electrical Engineering 348 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Motor Drives
description: Application to control speed and efficiency of motors using conventional thyristors control as well as modern variable frequency drives.

name: MEMS
description: MEMS (Microelectromechanical systems ) refers to devices and system with very small size in the range of microns. It is one of the most important high technologies developed in 20th century. This course covers the fundamentals of MEMS. It includes the introduction to MEMS, basic microfabrication techniques, MEMS materials and their properties, MEMS device design and simulation, working principle analysis, MEMS device fabrication sequence, MEMS packaging and assembly, signal testing, MEMS applications (inertial MEMS, MOEMS, BioMEMS, RFMEMS, etc ) 3 credit hours

name: Semiconductors
description: Crystal fabrication: MBE, MOCVD, LEC, Bridge Mann. Study material and electronic properties of single crystal Si, ploy, a-Si, GaAs, GaN, SiC, Ge and II-VI compounds. Transport properties: Hall Peltier, resistivity, mobility, Analysis of capacitance and I/V data for pn, pin, schottky and hetero-junction devices. Pre-requisite: Mathematics 110. 3 lecture hours, 3 semester hours

name: Microfabrication
